title: pregfindr
text: first step extraction specific claims records (marked codes stored codelists) services specific dates women within specific age boundaries. Different companies use different technologies store latest cut MarketScan. reason, providing example script can used guideline. Refer data extraction vignette. adapt data extraction step work storage system. Note: successful execution code, record sample size must sufficiently large. errors occur, likely due inadequate sample size. cases, consider expanding age range interest.

title: pregfindr
text: done first step, subset MarketScan. outcome records many patients follow format. can apply trimester hierarchy data reassign trimester codes claims different trimester codes service day. recommend store result disk. learn trimester reallocation hierarchy, encourage check Trimester Hierarchy vignette read function documentation utilities:
code: ?pregfindr::extraction_example library(pregfindr)  # Load data extraction results extraction_result <- arrow::read_parquet("extraction_result5060.parquet")  # Store file locally (TRUE / FALSE) trimester_hierarchy_save_locally <- FALSE trimester_hierarchy_filepath <- "commercial_trimester_hierarchy_final.parquet"  # Apply trimester hierarchy trimester_hierarchy_final <- apply_trimester_hierarchy(extraction_result)  # Saving results Locally ------- if (trimester_hierarchy_save_locally) {    arrow::write_parquet(trimester_hierarchy_final, trimester_hierarchy_filepath) } ?pregfindr::apply_trimester_hierarchy()

title: pregfindr
text: apply outcome hierarchy reassign pregnancy outcomes outcomes service day. learn outcome reallocation hierarchy, encourage check Outcome Hierarchy vignette read function documentation utilities:
code: # Store file locally (TRUE / FALSE) outcome_hierarchy_save_locally <- FALSE outcome_hierarchy_filepath <- "commercial_outcome_hierarchy_final.parquet"  # Apply outcome hierarchy outcome_hierarchy_final <- apply_outcome_hierarchy(trimester_hierarchy_final)  # Saving results Locally ------- if (outcome_hierarchy_save_locally) {    arrow::write_parquet(outcome_hierarchy_final, outcome_hierarchy_filepath) } ?pregfindr::apply_outcome_hierarchy()

what: 4. Estimate pregnancy start and end date
title: pregfindr
text: assign start end dates pregnancy. patients multiple outcomes, gestation weeks codes multiple trimester codes, overlapping start end dates can result. step applies hierarchies assign start end dates pregnancy episode patient. Due large number calculations, step really slow. learn pregnancy start end allocation hierarchy, encourage check Identifying Pregnancy Start End Dates vignette read function documentation utilities:
code: # Store file locally (TRUE / FALSE) outcome_start_end_date_save_locally <- FALSE pregnancy_data_cleaned_filepath <- "pregnancy_data_cleaned.parquet"  # Apply pregnancy start and end date hierarchy pregnancy_data_cleaned <- apply_pregnancy_start_end_hierarchy(outcome_hierarchy_final)  # Saving results Locally ------- if (outcome_start_end_date_save_locally) {    arrow::write_parquet(pregnancy_data_cleaned, pregnancy_data_cleaned_filepath) } ?pregfindr::apply_pregnancy_start_end_hierarchy()

code: @Manual{,   title = {pregfindr: Standardised Pregnancy Identification And Trimester Distribution In MarketScan},   author = {Federico Concas and Jaspreet Multani},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 1.0.0},   url = {https://gsk-biostatistics.github.io/pregfindr/}, }

title: Standardised Pregnancy Identification And Trimester Distribution In MarketScan
text: {pregfindr} open-source R implementation algorithm developed using two United States insurance claims databases identify pregnancies, pregnancy outcomes including losses, trimesters pregnancy length, based diagnostic procedure ontologies (ICD-9/10, CPT). algorithm described Sumner, K. M., Ehlinger, ., Georgiou, M. E., & Wurst, K. E. (2021). Development evaluation standardized pregnancy identification trimester distribution algorithms U.S. IBM MarketScan® Commercial Medicaid data. Birth defects research, 113(19), 1357–1367. https://doi.org/10.1002/bdr2.1954 Data medicine/vaccine safety typically generated post launch. Post marketing safety studies committed understanding medicine/vaccine uptake characteristics exposed pregnant women resulting sub-optimal study design robust data generated guide prescribing vulnerable population. Large real-world healthcare datasets rapid analytic query tools offer opportunity identify key areas public health concern optimise study approaches ensure benefit risk data generation population -served clinical research.
